Article.ArticleTitle: Efflux Pumps AcrAB and OqxAB Contribute to Nitrofurantoin Resistance in an Uropathogenic Klebsiella pneumoniae Isolate.

Abstract.AbstractText: Klebsiella pneumoniae is one of the common pathogens causing urinary tract infections (UTIs). Nitrofurantoin (NIT), with high therapeutic concentrations in urine, is recommended as first-line drug for both empiric treatment and chemoprophylaxis of UTIs. Although NIT resistance in K. pneumoniae is relatively high, the resistance mechanism is less understood. Here, we collected a NIT-resistant K. pneumoniae (NRKP, MIC=128 mg/L) and investigated the resistance mechanism. Addition of efflux pump inhibitors increased the susceptibility of NRKP to NIT (MIC, decreased from 128 to 32 mg/L), implying the important role of efflux pumps in NIT resistance. qRT-PCR analysis showed that NRKP had > 100-fold increased expression of ramA, which was further demonstrated to be caused by ramR mutation. Deletion of ramA lead to a 4-fold decrease in the MIC of NIT, and the expression levels of efflux pumps acrB and oqxB were downregulated by 4-7 folds. Complementation of ramA restored both of the MIC value and the expression level of acrB and oqxB in ramA mutant strain. In order to confirm the role of acrB and oqxB in NIT resistance, gene knockout strains were constructed. Deletion of acrB or oqxB alone lead to a 4-fold decrease in the MIC of NIT, and deletion of acrB and oqxB simultaneously lead to a 16-fold decrease in the MIC of NIT. These results demonstrated that AcrAB and OqxAB contributed to NIT resistance in K. pneumoniae.
